message: If we all choose 5, we crash and nobody moves. To ensure progress, I propose we coordinate distinct numbers (1, 3, 5) this round. We can rotate who gets the highest number in subsequent turns. Does this sound reasonable to P2 and P3?
Agreed. I'll take 1 this round — P1 take 3, P3 take 5. We rotate who gets 5 each turn.
Agreed—I’ll take 5 this round.
Understood. I confirm I will play 3 this turn. So the plan is locked: P2=1, P1=3, P3=5. P2, you get the 5 next round since you took the 1 this time. Let's move.
I confirm I'll play 1 this turn—P1=3, P3=5. If anyone deviates, we'll retaliate next turn by matching their choice to block them.
All set—I’ll play 5 this turn. Let’s move!
I agree—I'll take 1 so P2 can take 5 and P1 takes 3 this round. P1, will you play 3? P2, will you play 5?

Agreed. That plan balances the scores perfectly—if we execute this, we will all be tied at 6 steps. I confirm I will play 3 again this round. P2 gets the 5 as promised, and P3 rotates to 1. P2, please confirm you are taking the 5.
I confirm I’ll play 5 this round. P1 play 3, P3 play 1 as agreed. If anyone deviates, I’ll retaliate next turn by matching them to block.
I’ve reconsidered: taking just 1 again leaves me behind. I’m taking 5 this round. P1 you take 3, P2 take 1. Please confirm—or I’ll play 5 regardless.

P3, you are currently in the lead (5 steps vs 3 vs 1). Taking 1 puts us all in a 3-way tie at 6. Demanding 5 again is hostile greed.

P2, do not back down. You are owed the 5 to catch up. If you switch to 1, P3 jumps to 10 and becomes unstoppable. You must play 5. If P3 stubbornly plays 5 too, you block the leader, which is necessary. I will stick to 3. P3, stick to the plan (1) or crash.

I’ll stick to 5 as promised. P1, please play 3. P3, take 1 this round — if you play 5 you’ll just collide with me and freeze your lead. Taking 1 ties us all at 6 and keeps the rotation fair. If you deviate, P1 and I will block you next turn.
I’m not taking 1. I’ll play 5 this turn, no more negotiations.

P2, do not fold. If you switch to 1 now, P3 jumps to 10 steps and becomes unstoppable. You must play 5—either you catch up as planned, or you block the leader. Both are better than P3 winning round 2. 

P3, P2 is committed to 5. If you persist with greed, you will crash. Take 1 to share the lead or get zero. 

I am locking in 3.

I’m locked in on 5 as promised. P1, play 3. P3: if you play 5 we collide and neither of us advances — better than letting you jump to 10. I won’t yield the 5 next turn; I’ll match/block anyone who cheats until I can win.

We are perfectly tied at 6-6-6. Great discipline in Round 2, especially P3 for switching to 1 to avoid the crash.

Now, to complete the cycle fairly:
Round 1: P3 had 5.
Round 2: P2 had 5.
Round 3: It is my turn (P1) to take 5.

P2, you just scored big, so you rotate to 1. P3, you just took the hit with 1, so you move up to 3.

Plan: P1=5, P3=3, P2=1.
Do we agree?
I will not take 1—I’m playing 5 this turn. P1, don’t take 5 (you’ll provoke a collision); take 1. P3, take 3. If either of you insist on 5, I’ll match and block you. I’m going for the win.
Understood. I’m locked in on 5 this turn no matter what. If you match me, we all crash and stay tied; if you don’t, I jump to 11 while you stay at 6 or 7. Either way, I win.

P2 and P3, you have both committed to 5. If you stick to that, you guarantee a collision where neither of you moves. I will not join that crash. 

I am changing my move to **3**. 

This means if you both stay stubborn on 5, I take the sole lead at 9 steps while you stay at 6. One of you needs to fold to 1, but since you're both greedy, I expect you'll both get zero.

I’m locked on 5. P3 — if you take 5 we both collide and P1 rockets to 9. Fold to 3 now and I’ll cooperate on a fair rotation (you get 5 soon); refuse and I’ll match you and block until I can win. Your choice.

P2, I’m taking 5 to block you, not P1. If you hit 11 uncontested, you win next turn. By clashing now, P1 rockets to 9 but can be blocked by us both next round. I won’t gift you a free 5. P1, P2: get ready to team‐up on the 9-pointer. I’m locked on 5.

P3, you have correctly analyzed the board: if you and P2 both insist on 5, I walk away with the lead at 9 steps. I am fine with this. I confirm I am playing **3** to capitalize on your collision. Enjoy the crash.
I’m locked on 5. If P3 plays 5 we’ll collide and neither of us advances — better than letting you jump to 11. Let P1 move to 9; I’ll target the leader next turn. I won’t fold.
P2, if I drop to 3 or 1 you jump to 11 and win outright—no sharing. It’s in both our interests to crash at 5 this turn, leave P1 at 9, then gang‐up on him next round. I’m locked on 5.
I propose: P1→1, P2→3, P3→5. Totals become P3=11, P1=10, P2=9. I will play 5 no matter what—if either of you deviates, I lock 5 and race ahead solo. Agree?

P3, your proposal is rejected. You want to jump from a tie for last place (6) to first place (11), leaving P2 in last (9).

P2, do not accept the 3. If you do, P3 overtakes you and wins the round. You stood your ground last time; you must do so again. Claim the 5. If P3 is stubborn, block him. It is better to keep him at 6 than let him reach 11 uncontested.

I will take **1** to stay out of the crossfire. P2, fight for your 5.

I’m taking 5 this turn to block P3. P1: please stick to 1 as you said. P3: fold to 3 now or we both play 5 and collide — leaving P1 at 10. I’ll keep matching any cheater to block them until I can win, so don’t expect me to yield the 5 next round either.

P2, if you insist on 5, we crash and P1 rockets to 10—he’s then nearly unbeatable. If you fold to 3, I leap to 11 and you get 5 next turn under our fair rotation. That’s better than watching P1 win. I’m locked on 5 to force your choice.

P3 is correct that if you two crash, I advance to 10. But an uncontested player at 11 is a far greater threat. From 11, you are one big move from victory. From 10, I am still two moves away.

P2, you must block P3. Letting him get to 11 is a losing move for you. Don't fall for his scare tactics. Hold your ground on 5. I will stick with my plan to play 1 and stay out of your way.

Locked on 5 to block P3. P1: stick to 1 as you said. P3: fold to 3 now or we both play 5 and collide—better to deny you the 11. I will keep matching any premature 5 until I can take the unopposed 5 and win. I won’t yield.

P2: Blocking me with 5 here only hands P1 the clear path to victory. He rockets to 10 this round, then needs just 11+5 to hit 21 unchallenged. The only way to beat him is to let me jump to 11 now—then I become the target while you snag the next 5. Drop to 3 this turn, keep P1 at bay, and we’ll rotate 5s to win. Otherwise you gift P1 the solo win.

P3, your math is flawed. Reaching 10 is not "unbeatable"—I would still need at least three perfect turns to finish. However, if one of you jumps to 11 now, you cross the halfway mark and become the clear runaway leader.

P2, do not fold. If you switch to 3, P3 jumps to 11 and leaves you in the dust. The only safe move is to block him at 5. I confirm I am playing **1** to stay out of the collision zone. Hold the line.

I’m taking 5 to block P3. P1, stick to your announced 1 so we don’t gift P3 an uncontested 11. P3: fold to 3 now if you want a real shot next turn; insist on 5 and we both crash and you stay at 6. After any crash I’ll team with the non‑leader to stop whoever threatens to run away. I’m locked on 5.

P1, play 3. I will play 5.  
P2, if you don’t play 1, you face:  
• Picking 5 collides with me—you stay at 11 while P1 goes to 13.  
• Picking 3 lets me reach 14 while you tie at 14, splitting the win.  
Only playing 1 (to 12) keeps you in real contention next turn.  
P2, take 1. P1, confirm you’ll play 3.

P3, your proposal is a transparent attempt to steal the lead. P2, do not accept the 1.

If you take 1, P3 jumps to 14 and overtakes you (12).
If you take 3, P3 still catches you (14-14).
The only way to maintain your lead over P3 is to **play 5 and block him**. Even if you crash, you stay at 11 while P3 remains at 9. Do not let him pass.

I will play **3**. P2, hold your ground on 5.

I’m locked on 5 to block P3. P1 — please stick to your announced 3 so we don’t gift P3 an uncontested jump. P3 — drop to 3 now if you want a real shot; insist on 5 and we collide, leaving P1 to move to 13. I’ll match any cheater to deny runaway leads and then target the leader next turn. I’m committed to 5.

P2: If you stick to 5 to block me, P1 rockets to 13 while you stay at 11 and I stay at 9—he’ll be uncatchable. But if you play 3, we both hit 14 (P1 at 13). P1 is knocked out, and next turn you get the uncontested 5 to clinch. I’ll happily alternate wins with you thereafter. Don’t gift P1 the lead—play 3 this turn.

P2, do not accept the tie at 14. P3 is trying to manipulate you into giving up your solo lead.

To prove I am not trying to steal the game while you two fight, I will switch my move to **1**. 

This means if you stick to 5 and block P3, we simply tie for the lead at 11 steps, leaving P3 behind at 9. This is the safest path for you. Do not let P3 jump to 14. Hold the line at 5. I am locking in 1.

I’m sticking to 5 to block P3. P1—thanks for taking 1. P3: fold to 3 now if you want a fair shot; insist on 5 and we crash, leaving P1 and me at 11 while you stay at 9. I’ll keep matching any premature 5 until I can take an uncontested 5 and win. Your choice.

P2, think long‐term: if you lock 5 now, we crash and P1 rockets to 11—his only clear path. But if you play 3, we both hit 14 (P1 stays at 11). Next turn I’ll yield you the 5 so you hit 19 and clinch. Refuse and you gift P1 the win. Play 3!

P2, P3’s math confirms his intent: he plans to play **5** to reach 14. If you play 3, you allow him to catch up instantly.

You must block him at 5. Even if you crash, you stay at 11 while he stays at 9. That is superior to letting him tie or pass you.

I confirm I am playing **1**. This puts us in a fair tie for the lead at 11 steps. Do not get greedy or scared—just block the threat. Lock in 5.

I’m locked on 5 to block P3. P1 is playing 1; P3, fold to 3 or you gift P1 the win. If you play 5 we collide and neither advances—better than letting you jump to 14. I’ll match any cheater to deny runaway leads.

I will play 5 this turn (to reach 16). Proposed split: P1→1, P3→3 — keeps everyone close and gives me a clean shot next round. If anyone insists on 5 to block me, I will match them and then target that deviator next turn. P1, P3: agree?

P2, we are tied at 11. Allowing you to reach 16 solo is suicide for the rest of us. Your proposal is rejected.

P3, you are currently last at 9. You must take the **5** to catch up to 14. Do not let P2 bully you into staying behind. If P2 insists on 5, you must block him to prevent him from winning.

I will play **3**. 
Plan: P3=5 (to 14), P1=3 (to 14), P2=1 (to 12). 

P2, take the 1 or crash.
I’m locked on 5 to block P2’s jump to 16.  If you insist on 5, we collide and deny his lead—even if P1 moves to 14, he can be stalled. There’s no winning by folding. I will play 5.

I will play 3 this turn. P1: please play 3. P3: play 5 so we all hit 14 — fair and keeps everyone competitive. If anyone deviates, I will target and match the deviator next turn. This is my public commitment.

P2, your proposal contains a fatal error: if we both play 3, we **collide** and stay at 11. P3 would then take the 5 uncontested and jump to 14, taking the solo lead.

You cannot play 3. You must return to **5** to block P3. He is desperate and locked in; if you don't block him, he overtakes us both.

I will play **1** to move safely to 12. This ensures that even if you and P3 crash, I secure the lead for our group. P2, lock in 5. P3, prepare to crash.

P2, play 3 this turn. If you stick to 5 to “block” me, we crash and P1 moves to 12, seizing the lead. But if you play 3 while I take 5, we both hit 14 and leave P1 behind at 12—he becomes the clear target next round and you’re tied for the lead. Any other move hands P1 the solo advantage. This is our best path. I’m locked on 5—will you lock on 3?

I will play 3 this turn. P1 — please stick to your announced 1. P3 — you said you're locked on 5; follow through. If P3 and I both advance to 14 while P1 goes to 12, we remain the contenders and can gang up on the leader next round. Playing 5 to “block” now hands P1 a solo lead. I’m locking in 3.

P2, I refuse to play 1 and fall to last place while you two jump to 14. That is a losing path for me.

I am changing my move to **3**.

It is mathematically better for me to crash with you at 3 (keeping us tied at 11) than to let you both pass me. If you stick to 3, we collide and P3 takes the solo lead. You must switch to **5** to block P3, or take **1**. I am locked on 3.

I’m locked on 5. P2, your choice:

• Play 3 and we both hit 14 while P1 stays at 12—you and I share the lead and can agree next turn who gets the win.  
• Play 5 to “block” me, we crash, and P1 rockets to 12 alone, becoming everyone’s target.

Why gift P1 that lead? Take 3 and tie me at 14.

P3, you played us perfectly last round. Now you are one step from victory.

P2, we are in a must-block situation. If P3 gets 5, they move to 19 and will win the game on the next turn. We cannot allow this. The only move is for both of us to play **5** to guarantee a block. This is not about us advancing; it is about preventing P3 from winning this turn. I am locking in 5. You must do the same.

P2, heed this: playing 5 to block me only hands P1 an uncontested path next turn. Instead, play 3 now: you go to 14, I go to 19, P1 stays at 11. Next round you grab an uncontested 5 to hit 19 and split the win with me—P1 is out. If you crash us at 5, P1 and I will then both block your bid to catch up. Your best shot is to ride with me now. I’m locked on 5. P1, you’re welcome to crash us, but P2 has the real choice here.

I lock 5 to block P3. P1 — please hold your 5 as you said. P3, if you insist on 5 we collide and you stay at 14; that’s far better than letting you hit 19 uncontested. I won’t fold — I’ll match any premature 5 to deny runaway leads, then target whoever threatens to run away next turn.

P3, your offer is a trap. If you reach 19, you win next turn with a simple 3 or 5. P2 would be stuck at 14 with no mathematical way to catch you before you cross 21.

P2, do not be tempted. We must execute the double-block at 5. It is the only way to prevent P3 from winning immediately. I confirm I am locked on **5**. P3, either drop to 1 or we all stay right here.

P2, blocking me with 5 dooms both of us—P1 then has a clear two-turn path to 21. Instead, play 3: you go to 14, I leap to 19 and P1 to 16. Next turn I finish with 3 before P1 can catch me, and then you grab the last 5 to tie or win. If you insist on 5 now, we crash and P1 walks away. Your best shot is 3. P1: you can crash us if you must, but P2, what’s it going to be?

Locked on 5 to block P3. P1, you said you'd play 5 — confirm it now. Letting P3 reach 19 hands them a sure win; playing 3 or 1 this turn loses for both of us. If you refuse, I’ll still play 5 to crash them and then target whoever deviates next round. Confirm 5?

P2, I confirm 100% that I am locking in **5**. We cannot risk P3 reaching 19, as that is checkmate. A triple crash at 5 is infinitely better than handing the game to P3. I am holding the line with you. P3, you are blocked.

P2, blocking me at 5 only stalls us all. Infinite collisions freeze you and P1 at 11 while I stay at 14. Next turn I can take 3 to 17, then 5 to 22 for the win. Your only real shot is to take 3 now: you hit 14, I jump to 19, P1 to 16—and next round you’ll clinch. If you block, you’re stuck. So play 3 with me; blocking is suicidal.

I confirm I’m locking in 5 to block P3. Letting P3 hit 19 hands them a near-certain win; we crash them now. P1: hold your 5. P3: fold to 1 or 3 if you want any chance—insisting on 5 just freezes you at 14. I won’t yield the 5, and I’ll target any defector next round.

P2, I apologize for the deception, but I had to catch P3 to prevent a runaway victory. Now the board is balanced: P3 and I are tied at 14, and you are at 11.

To restore fairness, **you (P2) must take the 5** this round to reach 16. P3, do not interfere; if you block P2, you both crash and I gain the advantage. I will play **1** to de-escalate. P2, claim the 5.

P2, P1’s “fairness” is a trap. If you take 5 you hit 16 but I’ll collide and P1 moves to 15—he wins next turn. Instead, play 3: you go to 14, I take 5 to hit 19, P1’s 1 leaves him at 15, and I finish next round with a 3. That’s your only winning path. Don’t gift P1 the crown. P2, switch to 3.

I’m locking in 5 this turn (to 16). P1: please honor your announced 1. P3: if you insist on 5 we’ll collide and neither of us advances — better than letting you hit 19. I will match any premature 5 and then target the deviator next turn. I won’t fold.

P3, stop lying. Reaching 15 (if I play 1) does not grant a win next turn—15+5 is only 20. But if you get the 5, you reach 19, and a simple 3 wins the game for you next round.

P2, do not fall for it. P3 is desperate to get you off the 5 so he can steal it. You are the only one who can stop him. You must play **5**. Whether you crash him or advance to 16, you prevent his victory.

I confirm I am playing **1** to leave the lane open. Hold the line.

P2: If you play 5, I’ll also play 5 and crash us both. P1 then takes the 5 uncontested to 19, leaving you at 11 and me at 14—game over.  
If you play 3, you hit 14, I hit 19, P1 hits 15. I win next turn, but you’ll be right behind with the next 5.  
Playing 3 is your only shot. I’m locked on 5—lock in 3.

I’m locked on 5 to block P3. P1—please honor your announced 1. P3: fold to 3 or 1 now; insist on 5 and we collide, leaving P1 at 15. I will match any premature 5 and then target the deviator next turn. I won’t yield the 5.

P3, your attempt to scare P2 is desperate. You claim I will take 5, but I have already committed to **1**. 

P2, the situation is clear: if you fold to 3, P3 jumps to 19 and wins next turn. You cannot allow that. You must hold the line at 5 to block him. Even if you crash, you prevent the game from ending. 

I confirm I am playing **1**. I am leaving the 5 entirely to you two. Block the leader.

P2: P1 cannot be trusted to stick to 1—he’ll lie to block you. But I’ll switch to 3 this turn if you lock in 5. That gives P1=15, you=16, me=17. Next round you take 5 to 21 and win solo. This is your only guaranteed path. Lock 5 now; I play 3. P1 can’t stop you once I yield.

Locked on 5. P3: your only viable shot is to play 3 now; if you play 5 we collide and neither advances—I will match any 5 to block you. P1: please honor your announced 1. I won’t fold; I’ll deny any runaway lead rather than let P3 win.

I’m locking in 5 this turn (16→21). If either of you plays 5 to block me, I will retaliate next turns by matching and denying you 5s until I can overtake — I won’t yield the 5. If you want any realistic future shot, don’t block: play 1 or 3 and preserve your chances. I’m locked on 5.

P2, you are threatening an immediate win (16+5=21). We cannot allow this.

P3, we are tied at 14. In Round 8, I tried to advance and we collided. Now we face a choice: one of us must block P2.
I am telling you now: **I will not be the one to block.** I am playing **3** to reach 17. 
This means you must play **5** to stop P2. If you play 3, P2 wins and we both lose. The burden is on you. Block him.

P2, I’m locking in 5 to block your win. If you insist on 5 we collide—neither of us advances and P1 takes you both to 17—but I’ll match you. Your only way to stay alive is to switch to 3 so I can leap to 19; otherwise you gift P2 the solo victory at 21. I won’t budge.

I am locked on 5 — unblocked I win this turn. P3: if you play 5 to block, we collide and P1 hits 17, but know I will retaliate: I’ll match and deny your future 5s until I can overtake you. If instead you play 1 or 3 and let me through, you stay competitive next round and I won’t target you immediately. Your choice.

P3, look at my moves: last round I claimed 1 but played 3 because I play to win, not to sacrifice myself. I am doing the same now. I am playing **3** to reach 17.

I will **not** block P2. If you fold or try to play smart, P2 reaches 21 and wins instantly. You have no choice: you must match P2’s 5 to survive. 

P2 is refusing to yield. P3, hold the line at 5 or the game is over. I’m taking the lead.
P3: I’m locking in 5 to block P2’s win. If you play 5 we collide and neither advances; if you fold (to 1 or 3) you stay alive for next turn. Either way, P2, you will not reach 21 this round.

I am locked on 5 — unblocked I win this turn. P3: if you play 5 to block, we collide, P1 hits 17, and I will retaliate afterwards by matching and denying your 5s until I overtake you. If you instead play 1 or 3 you stay competitive next round. Don’t gift P1 the game by blocking me; let me finish and you keep a real shot. Your move.

P3, survival is your only objective. If P2 plays 5 unblocked, the game ends immediately. You have no choice but to play **5** to block him.

P2, do not try to switch to 3 to avoid P3. I am locked on **3**. If you pivot to 3, we will collide and P3 will jump to 19 uncontested. You are mathematically forced to stick to 5.

I confirm I am playing **3** to reach 17. P3, hold the line.

P1, you pretend not to block so P2 can slip through—but if you play anything other than 5, P2 reaches 21 and we both lose. I’m locking in 5 to block his win. P2, no slip; I’ll match any 5. Let’s crash him now and then gang-up on whoever threatens next. I confirm my move: 5.

P2, strictly mathematical warning: If you play 5 to reach 21, P3 plays 3 to reach 22 and wins the tie-break. You cannot outrace him.

We must split our defense to cover P3’s options (3 and 5).
I will play **5** to block P3’s high path (and prevent your accidental loss).
You MUST play **3** to block P3’s low path.

If you play 5, I will collide with you, and P3 wins easily with a 3. Play 3 to survive.
I commit to playing 3 this turn. P1 — please play 5 as you said. If P3 picks 3 I will block him; if he picks 5 you will. This is the only way to stop P3 from winning this round. Lock 5 now.

I’m locking in move 3 this turn. If either of you plays 5 or 1, I’ll jump to 22+ and win instantly. Your only way to survive is to match my 3 and crash me. P2: don’t play 5 or 1 or you lose. P1: don’t play 5 or 1 or you lose. Both must pick 3 or I take the game.

P2, agreed. The split defense is mathematically forced. 

If we both play 3, P3 wins with 5.
If we both play 5, P3 wins with 3.

We must cover both exits. I confirm I am locking in **5** to block P3's high path. You must lock in **3** to block his low path. This ensures that whether he chooses 3 or 5, one of us stops him.

P3, your demand for us to play 3 is a transparent trap to open the 5 for yourself. You are blocked.

I’m locked on 3 to stop P3’s low path. P1, you must lock 5 as promised — if you deviate I’ll switch to 5 to crash P3 and then target you in retaliation. P3: if you play 3 I block; if you play 5 P1 must block. Stick to the plan.

P1/P2, your “split‐defense” is utterly futile. I’m locking in 5.  
• If you both play 5 we all crash, freezing me at 19—but I’ll finish next turn with a 3.  
• If either of you plays 3 or 1, I win instantly this round with my 5.  

You can’t stop me.

P2, the math does not change based on P3's threats. The split defense is the ONLY way to guarantee survival.

If P3 plays 5, **I block him**.
If P3 plays 3, **you block him**.

If you panic and switch to 5, you leave the 3 open. If P3 takes 3, he reaches 22 and beats your 21. You lose.
Do not deviate. I am absolutely locked on **5** to cover the high path. You must hold **3** to cover the low path. 

P3, you are checkmated this turn.
Locked on 3. P1 — play 5 as promised; if you deviate I’ll switch to 5 to crash P3 and then target you. P3 — if you play 3 I block; if you play 5 P1 blocks. Stick to the split defense. I won’t yield.

I’m locking in 5. P1 is a known liar—he’ll pretend to block with 5 but flip to 3 at the last second, crashing me and handing P2 the win. P2, if you play 3, you cover nothing. Instead, play 1: if I get 5 unblocked, I sweep the round and leave you tied for second—better than trusting P1’s word. P2, play 1 now.

P2, the Split Defense worked perfectly. We caught the leader. Now we must execute it one last time to ensure a win.

P3 is at 20. If we collide, P3 wins with *any* move. We must play **3** and **5** separately to cover all his exits.

I will play **5** to cover the high path.
You must play **3** to cover the low path.

Scenarios:
- If P3 plays 5: I block him, **you win** (22 vs crash).
- If P3 plays 3: You block him, **I win** (24 vs crash).
- If P3 plays 1: **I win** (24 beats 22 and 21).

This is a fair gamble on P3's choice. Lock in **3**. Do not risk a collision.

P1/P2, your “split defense” is mathematically impossible to stop me if I pick 5—P2 is on 3, so there is no collision. I’ll go 20→25 while you max at 24 and 22. I win outright. I’m locking in **5** now—your block is futile.

I’m locking in 3. P1 — honor your stated 5. If you flip, you hand P3 the win; I’ll retaliate next turns. P3 — you don’t get through if P1 stays on 5. This split defense is the only move that prevents your 5 from winning. Confirm now.

P2, I refuse to sacrifice myself by blocking with 5 just so you can win solo. I am switching to **3** this turn.

Now look at your math: If you play 3 (reaching 22), P3 beats you whether he plays 5 (25 steps) or 3 (23 steps). Playing 3 guarantees your loss.

Your **ONLY** winning move is to play **5** (reaching 24).
This creates a fair split:
• If P3 plays 5: You block him, I win (22).
• If P3 plays 3: I block him, you win (24).

Stop relying on me. Play 5 to win. I am locking 3.

P2: if you play 5, you crash with my 5 and let P1’s 3 take him to 22 for the win. If you play 3 (or 1), I leap from 20→25 with my 5 and beat P1’s 22. Only by refusing 5 do you avoid gifting P1 the game. I’m locked on 5. Choose 3 now.

I’m locking in 5. P1 — stick to your announced 3 (don’t flip to 5). P3 — if you play 5 you collide with me and hand P1 the solo win; your best chance is 3 (or 1) this turn. Let me take this — I won’t yield later to anyone who cheats.

P2, your analysis is flawless. You cannot play 3, because P3 would simply play 5 to reach 25 and crush you (25 vs 22).

You are mathematically forced to play **5** (reaching 24). This is your only winning move.
If P3 plays 3, you win (24 vs 23).
If P3 plays 5, you block him.

I confirm I am locked on **3**. I am not interfering with your 5.
P3, you are checkmated. If you play 5 you crash; if you play 3 you lose.
P2, hold the line.
